#Text=Mohammad Beg
#Text=Mohammad Beg ( Persian : محمد بیگ‎ ; died 1672 ) , was a Muslim of Armenian origin , who served as the Grand Vizier of the Safavid king ( shah ) Abbas II ( r. 1642 – 1666 ) from 1654 to 1661 .
#Text=Origins
#Text=Mohammad Beg was born in Tabriz to an Armenian family , which originally served as a ghulām ( " military slave " ) of the Safavid dynasty of Iran , but later became tailors . [ 1 ]

column1: #Text=Mohammad Beg 's father was Husayn Beg Tabrizi , who served as the court master tailor ( qaychachi-bashi ) during the reign of Shah Safi ( r. 1629 – 1642 ) . [ 1 ] [ 2 ]
#Text=Biography
#Text=Mohammad Beg is first mentioned in 1643 , when he was appointed as the city prefect of New Julfa , a quarter in the Safavid capital of Isfahan , which was populated by Armenians .

#Text=During this period , Mohammad Beg was supported by another officer of Armenian origin named Allahverdi Khan ( not be confused with the powerful military officer Allahverdi Khan , who was of Georgian origin ) . [ 3 ]
#Text=In 1646 , Mohammad Beg was appointed as the port-master/harbourmaster ( shahbandar ) of Bandar Abbas . [ 1 ]
#Text=Two years later , he was appointed as the " controller of assay " ( mu'ayyir al-mamalik ) . [ 4 ] [ 1 ]
#Text=With the help of Allahverdi Khan , Mohammad Beg became the steward of the royal household ( nazer-e boyutat ) in 1651 , thus succeeding Mohammad Ali Beg .
#Text=One year later , Mohammad Beg was appointed as the governor of Kohgiluyeh .
#Text=However , during the same year , Mohammad Beg 's relations with Allahverdi Khan became bad , and the two became rivals . [ 1 ]
#Text=In 1654 , Mohammad Beg was appointed by shah Abbas II as his grand vizier .
#Text=One of his first acts was dismissing the Georgian prefect of Isfahan , Parsadan Gorgijanidze , due to his unpopularity among the inhabitants of the city . [ 5 ] [ 6 ]
#Text=Mohammad Beg also had the empire more centralized by converting more land into the crown domain ( Hamadan in 1654 , Ardabil in 1656/7 , Semnan in 1656/7 and Kerman in 1658 ) . [ 7 ] [ 8 ] [ 9 ]
#Text=In 1661 , Mohammad Beg , after having failed to diminish the power of his rivals , was forced to resign from the grand vizier office . [ 10 ]
#Text=He was then exiled to Qom .
#Text=In 1672 , shah Suleiman I ( r. 1666 – 1694 ) offered Mohammad Beg to become grand vizier once again , which he agreed to , but while on his way to Isfahan , he died .
#Text=According to the French traveler Jean Chardin , Mohammad Beg had been poisoned by Suleiman 's grand vizier Shaykh Ali Khan Zangana . [ 11 ]
#Text=Family
#Text=Mohammad Beg had a son named Amin Beg , who would later serve as the mu'ayyir al-mamalik in Isfahan .
#Text=Mohammad Beg 's two brothers , Ughan Beg and Husayn Beg , both served as the shahbandar of Bandar Abbas .
#Text=Their uncle , Shamshir Beg , also served in the office , and was succeeded by Mohammad Beg 's cousin Isa Khan Beg . [ 12 ]
#Text=When Mohammad Beg was appointed as the nazer-e boyutat in 1651 , he gave his previous office , mu'ayyir al-mamalik , to one of his other brother , Hasan Beg . [ 12 ]
#Text=Furthermore , when Mohammad Beg was appointed grand vizier , he appointed Hasan Beg as the qaychachi-bashi . [ 12 ]
#Text=Furthermore , one of Mohammad Beg 's nephews served as the vizier of the governor of Gilan .
#Text=During most of the reign of Abbas II , all of silver and silk commerce was controlled by the family of Mohammad Beg . [ 10 ]
